problem_text: Let G be a finite group acting irreducibly on a vector space V . An orbit αG for α ∈ V is said to be p-regular if the stabilizer of α in G is a p′-subgroup. Does G have a regular orbit on V if it has a p-regular orbit for every prime p? Jiping Zhang
answer: No, not always. For example, let H = A4≀Z5, V = O2(H), and G be a complement to V in H, G acting on V by conjugation. (V. I. Zenkov, Letter of February, 11, 1994.)
